title: How Donald Trump is rewriting US history
subhead: As the country marks its 250th anniversary this year, the American president, who returned to the White House on January 20, 2025, has worked to shape a revised historical narrative, revealing signs of megalomania.

title: Super Bowl 2026: Seahawks soar to 29-13 win over the Patriots
Bad Bunny brings Puerto Rico's culture to a revolutionary Super Bowl halftime show, with a surprise Lady Gaga appearance
AI's impact on entire sectors of the economy shakes Wall Street
subhead: Investors have abandoned sectors like software in favor of the traditional Dow Jones, which has broken through the 50,000-point mark.

title: PSG pound Marseille and move back to top of Ligue 1
subhead: Luis Enrique's Paris Saint-Germain, who beat Marseille 5-0 on Sunday, have now won seven straight league matches, though they remain under pressure from surprise challengers Lens, who briefly moved to the top slot on Saturday and sit just two points behind.

title: French cosmetics sales drop in the US after being struck by tariffs
subhead: French production has struggled in the United States, its leading export market, amid competition from Korean brands.

title: Mayor and mother: The young women changing France's local councils
subhead: Only 41 women under the age of 30 were elected as mayors in 2020, out of France's 34,885 mayors. Here are the stories of several women who have balanced their careers, motherhood and first terms in office in a political scene often dominated by older men.

At Centre Pompidou-Metz, the late resurrection of sculptor Louise Nevelson
subhead: The American artist, known in the 1960s for her monumental and forbidding installations, is on display at the Moselle museum.

title: 'Dependence on the US is deeply rooted in the European mindset'
subhead: Europe continues to struggle to find its own voice on the international stage because it remains trapped in a cognitive dependence on Washington, writes Rosa Balfour, director of the Carnegie Europe think tank.

title: Julian Barnes bids farewell: 'There's no such thing as a perfect novel'
subhead: The British writer has published what he says will be his final book, 'Departure(s)', as he celebrates his 80th birthday. He welcomed Le Monde into his home in London for a wide-ranging conversation on his career as a writer and his body of work.
